Bandit: Rejection Sampling Offline Evaluation

RejectionSamplingOfflineBandit uses data from a randomly assigned policy for offline evaluation.

Details

The key assumption of the method is that the individual events are i.i.d., and that the logging policy chose each arm at each time step uniformly at random. Take care: if A is a stationary policy that does not change over trials, data may be used more efficiently via propensity scoring (Langford et al., 2008; Strehl et al., 2011) and related techniques like doubly robust estimation (Dudik et al., 2011).

Usage

bandit <- RejectionSamplingOfflineBandit(data_file, k, d)

References

Li, L., Chu, W., Langford, J., & Wang, X. (2011, February). Unbiased offline evaluation of contextual-bandit-based news article recommendation algorithms. In Proceedings of the fourth ACM international conference on Web search and data mining (pp. 297-306). ACM.

See also

Core contextual classes: Contextual, Simulator, Agent, History, Plot, Policy

Other contextual bandits: DoublyRobustOfflineBandit

Examples


horizon            <- 100L
